Description: The Securities and Exchange Commission announced that Jefferies LLC settled allegations of with failing to supervise employees on its mortgage-backed securities desk who were lying to customers about pricing.

Jefferies & Co., Inc. agreed to pay $4.2 million in disgorgement to settle allegations that two of its executives spent approximately $2 million on improper gifts, travel, entertainment and other gratuities given to win mutual fund trading business.

The Justice Department's Antitrust Division, at the request of the Federal Trade Commission, filed a civil antitrust lawsuit in U.S. District Court in Washington, D.C., against Leucadia National Corporation for violating the premerger notification and waiting period requirements of the Hart-Scott-Rodino Act of 1976 when it acquired voting securities of KCG Holdings Inc. in July 2013.  At the same time, the department filed a proposed settlement, subject to approval by the court, under which Leucadia has agreed to pay a $240,000 civil penalty to resolve the lawsuit.

Notes: Year is fiscal year. Date is closing date.

Info Source: Extracted from a download of OSHA's Enforcment Data downloaded on 3/02/2022, available at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_catalogs.php

Agency: Connecticut Securities and Business Investments Division

Description: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority fined Jefferies & Company, Inc. $1.5 million for failing to disclose additional compensation received and conflicts in connection with the sale of auction rate securities (ARS). FINRA also ordered Jefferies to repay $425,000 in fees and commissions earned from the sale of ARS to the affected customers
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Description: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority fined 19 broker-dealers a total of $2.8 million for substantially overstating their advertised trade volume to three private service providers.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Description: NASD fined Jefferies & Company, Inc. $5.5 million for providing more than $1.6 million in improper gifts and entertainment to equity traders employed by FMR Co., Inc., an investment advisor to the Fidelity family of mutual funds, between Sept. 3, 2002, and Oct. 11, 2004.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).
